entries.content: Give yourself permission to be bad at selling to get good at it.
Don't focus on the outcome or how prospects view you; focus on trying uncomfortable things to improve.
In cold outreach, accept that some people will react negatively. Do it anyway to reach those who need help.
Fear of sounding bad or fumbling hinders sales growth. Practice is the only way to improve.
Record your sales calls and demos.
Listen back to recordings to identify specific areas for improvement.
Practice improving specific weaknesses identified from recordings.
Research and write scripts for common objections encountered.
Roleplay objection responses repeatedly until they become natural.
Use recordings to identify communication issues like interrupting, talking too fast, or monotonous tone.
Roleplay sales scenarios daily, preferably with others.
The purpose of roleplaying is practice, not perfection; practice handling fumbling, objections, and awkward silences.
Roleplaying difficult situations builds resilience for real calls.
Script the opening (first 15 seconds) for every type of sales interaction (cold call, demo, follow-up).
Confidence in your opening is crucial; not having it leads to stumbling and lost confidence.
Sales is fundamentally about human psychology.
Learn sales psychology: why people buy/don't buy, motivation, persuasion, trust, urgency, resistance.
Understanding psychology is key to consistent closing beyond just following scripts or asking questions.
Study specific psychological principles like anchoring, reciprocity, social proof, scarcity, urgency, and loss aversion.
Implement psychological principles in your sales process.
Learning sales psychology is a major driver of improvement.
Track your sales metrics: calls, conversations, meetings booked, demos, proposals, deals closed, average deal size, close rate.
What gets measured gets improved. Know your numbers intimately.
Analyze conversion rates between metrics to diagnose bottlenecks (e.g., conversations to meetings, demos to closes).
Identify bottlenecks via metrics and focus improvement efforts specifically on those areas.
Get feedback on your sales performance regularly.
Feedback is necessary to identify what you're doing wrong and improve.
Seek feedback by having others listen to your calls/demos or watch your pitches/presentations.
Get feedback specifically on areas identified for improvement through metrics and recordings.
Seek actionable feedback: specific suggestions for alternative actions with reasoning, not just general comments.
